text:
This video is brought to you by NordVPN - get
75% off via the link below.

Today we’ll be taking a look at some cases
of localization and translation from the Dragon

Quest series - a RPG series that has a history
of more than 30 years and continues to be

one of the most celebrated RPG franchises
to have come from Japan.

First appearing in Dragon Quest VIII, is a
reoccurring gag that’s been remembered by
fans for its humorous and quirky nature.

In the game is a catchphrase that comes up
at certain points, where characters, specifically

female ones, will be described as being “va
va voom”.

What adds to this is the stark contrast between
this term and the very medieval inspired nature

of the game and of course its distinctively
Japanese origins.

In the first town that you go to upon embarking
on your quest, you will be able to find a

NPC who is a young girl and says “My dad
says women like Miss Jessica are really ‘va
va voom’.”

The voluptuous Jessica is one of the main
characters of the game and one of the playable
party members.

She lives in the town and you will soon join
up with her during this section of the game.

The girl then adds – “What do you think
he means?
I wonder if I can be ‘va va voom’?”

The term va va voom has been traced back to
the 1954 American song “Va Va Va Voom”
by Art Carney.

Over time “va va va voom”, got shortened
to just “va va voom” and is used to describe
something that is exciting or physically attractive.

The term became especially well known following
a popular series of Renault commercials in

the early 2000s, featuring footballer Thierry
Henry.

Due to it being released around the same time,
it is possible that these commercials played

a part in the catchphrase being included in
the game.

You can find the phrase mentioned when interacting
with the same NPC whilst she is sleeping,

where she is curiously so compelled by it
that she utters the words whilst sound asleep.

Then, it gets brought again during a much
later section of the game, where King Clavious

is trying to convince the prince to marry
Princess Medea.

Whilst at first he says he has no interest
in getting married, this soon changes when

the King describes the princess’ beauty
and how va va voom she is.

However, the reason that the channel is taking
a look at this relates to how all of this

is, instead, in the Japanese version of the
game.

And not just Dragon Quest VIII but other games
in the franchise too.

In Japan, the term va va voom wasn’t used
in any parts of the game and it’s quite

unlikely that Japanese players would understand
what this term meant.

Instead, in the Japanese version is a reoccurring
gag where females are described as “bon
kyu bon”.

Bonkyubon is a Japanese mimetic term that
can be broken down to down to bon, which can

mean big, kyu which can mean small and then
bon again.

And so, put them together and you have bonkyubon,
meaning big-small-big.

This is a term used to describe a curvy hourglass-like
figure, with a big bust, small waist and then
big hips.

For instance, in only April of this year,
Sumire Uesaka who is a popular voice actor

and singer has released a song entitled Bon
Kyu Bon wa Kare no Mono and the song is all
about being bon kyu bon.

So, in all instances of va va voom in the
English version, bon kyu bon is used instead

and, aside from this, the translations are
virtually identical to the English.

The Japanese version of the game didn’t
have any voice acting unlike over in the west.

However, this changed with the release of
the much later 3DS version and so now we can
hear this line dubbed in Japanese as well.

But, that’s not all, bon kyu bon was also
used in other parts of the game where va va

voom wasn’t over in the west and, like mentioned,
is a much bigger reoccurring gag in the Japanese

franchise ever since its appearance in the
8th game.

In fact, there’s even a whole Japanese wiki
page devoted to appearances of bon kyu bon
in the series.

Another instance where it appears in Dragon
Quest VIII is in some hidden dialogue you

can get right at the end of the game when
introducing yourself to the Dragovian Council
of Elders.

Normally the dialogue will be the same when
speaking to all of the characters, however,

if you switch the field character to Jessica
before talking to one of the elders, the dialogue
will be drastically different.

An elderly female council member somehow confuses
Jessica for a male and says that she has grown
into a fine young man.

This then prompts Jessica to exclaim how she
is a women and she explains, to quote, “I’ve
got... and I haven’t got...
I mean, there are obvious differences!”

In the Japanese version though, bon kyu bon
is once again mentioned, with Jessica instead

saying to the elderly lady – “can you
not see this bon kyu bon?”

Which is of course referring to her feminine
figure.

The term has also appeared in the latest game
in the series, Dragon Quest XI, and the Japanese-exclusive
3DS version.

In the 3DS release is a number of post game
areas, where you can revisit some of the areas

and characters from previous Dragon Quest
games.

The Dragon Quest VIII area features a side
quest involving collecting various books for

Jessica’s mother, in order to improve Jessica’s
personality.

One of these books is an “etchi na hon”,
which translates in English to an erotic book.

And then when you give this book to Jessica,
she transforms into an exaggerated humorous

and erotic personality, where she once again
starts to proudly talk about her bon kyu bon.

What do you think about how the English localization
of Dragon Quest VIII handled bon kyu bon and

how do you feel about it being more of a reoccurring
part of the franchise over in Japan?

As always please let us know your thoughts
in the comments below and consider subscribing

to see more videos on regional differences
in video games.
Until next time, thank you for watching.
